task.title: Create workflow: "Supplier invoice reconciliation"

data.title: Create workflow: "Supplier invoice reconciliation"
data.body:
/bounty 100

1. Download the app https://app.mediar.ai/
2. Create 'New' workflow
3. Prompt AI in the chat to create it
4. Adjust and correct the steps to make it work reliably
5. Deploy to the dashboard
6. Ask me questions in the comments please

Requirements:
- CHECK IF ANYONE ALREADY started working on the issue in the comments below
- comment /attempt to start working on the issue
- as part of submission you need to create a screen recording to show that the workflow works on your end, end-to-end

Output table destination:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1P7tioZ7sC3GdP5aOSrBhYKb_svkFjDbTransEqDMqvA/edit?gid=0#gid=0

task.title: create a TS workflow that delete the oldest version of PyPI before publishing to PyPI

data.title: create a TS workflow that delete the oldest version of PyPI before publishing to PyPI
data.body:
/bounty 100 


problem:
- cannot publish pypi bcs there is limit of versions 
- there is no api / cli to do that so we need to do this w UI 

definition of done:
- before publishing to pypi the gh action runs a TS workflow that delete oldest pypi release 
- share video it works (use your own pypi account for the video idk)

task.title: create a typescript workflow that test the browser script bridge

data.title: create a typescript workflow that test the browser script bridge
data.body:
/bounty 100

should be able to reproduce this:

```
Failed to enable debugger domains: Debugger is not attached to the tab with id: 648628626.
```

example ts workflow:

https://github.com/mediar-ai/terminator/tree/main/examples/simple_notepad_workflow


definition of done:
- uses workflow sdk, terminator sdk, can be ran one liner using terminator cli 
- test different edge cases of the rust bridge using UI (executeBrowserScript function)
- PR with video showing it runs 
- make it run in our github action

task.title: [bounty] test and showcase the new gemini computer use model with terminator MCP

data.title: [bounty] test and showcase the new gemini computer use model with terminator MCP
data.body:
basic idea: try the new gemini CU model:

https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/computer-use

and try to build some workflows like reading PDFs or spreadsheets on file system and doing data entry in another software 


goal: evaluate if their model adds worthwhile performance gain by using both vision and accessibility to build workflow compared to claude etc


requirements:
- record yourself building the workflow 
- use the new model somehow (gemini CLI + terminator MCP + gemini model configured for example, or build a custom MCP client in python/js, high preference for JS)
- use terminator MCP server


bonus:
- professional video level that can be published on social


please share your plan before building things, one-prompt PRs will be banned 

/bounty 200

task.title: [bounty] $400 fix audio device randomly stopping sometimes

data.title: [bounty] $400 fix audio device randomly stopping sometimes
data.body:
display audio / microphone randomly stops on mac sometimes 

had it running for 48h now and display audio somehow stopped a bit later after 50h

/bounty 400 

@EzraEllette any idea?


i suggest finding way to reproduce and then some automated test and a fix

task.title: [feature]  Implement Session Tracking for Application and Window Usage

data.title: [feature]  Implement Session Tracking for Application and Window Usage
data.body:
## Challenge

I'm working on an application that requires accurate session tracking to analyze user behavior patterns,  and provide meaningful insights across different applications and windows. 

In the existing Screenpipe architecture, OCR data is stored with only timestamp information, lacking precise session boundaries (start/end times) for application usage tracking. This limitation prevents us from properly segmenting user activity into coherent sessions.

## 1. Current Workaround
internally I implementing a suboptimal solution that:
1. Queries all OCR database entries chronologically
2. Manually identifies session boundaries by analyzing timestamp sequences for each application
3. Determines session end when detecting a different application in subsequent timestamps
4. Assumes a session is ongoing if no clear delimiter exists in future timestamps

With that said I would love to hear any feedbacks that could help solve this problem with a minimal overhead on code changes, and make sure I'm not overthinking the solution: cc @louis030195 , i'm planning to start playing with some day next week

## 2. Requirements

1.  **Session Definition:** A "session" should be defined as a continuous period of user interaction with a specific application and window.  A break in activity (e.g., switching to a different application or window) should end the current session and potentially start a new one.  A configurable inactivity timeout (e.g., 5 minutes) should also end a session.

2.  **Data Storage:** The database schema must be modified to store session start and end times, associated with specific applications and windows.  It must maintain links to the relevant OCR and audio data chunks.

3.  **API Endpoint:**  A new or modified API endpoint (e.g., `/sessions`) is needed to query for session data.  This endpoint should support filtering by:
    *   Date range (start and end timestamps).
    *   Application name.
    *   Window name.
    *   Minimum and maximum session duration.
    *   Associated tags.
    *   Pagination (limit and offset).

4.  **Real-time Capability:** The system should be able to detect session boundaries in near real-time as data is being ingested. This implies integration with the existing data capture and processing pipeline.

5. **Configurability:** The inactivity timeout for ending a session should be configurable.

## 3. Proposed Solution

### 3.1. Database Schema Changes

We'll introduce a new table `sessions` and modify the existing tables.

**New Table: `sessions`**

| Column Name      | Data Type  | Constraints                                  | Description                                                                  |
| :--------------- | :--------- | :------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `id`             | INTEGER    | PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT                    | Unique identifier for the session.                                       |
| `app_name`       | TEXT       | NOT NULL                                     | Name of the application.                                                 |
| `window_name`    | TEXT       |                                               | Title of the window.                                                     |
| `start_time`     | DATETIME   | NOT NULL                                     | Timestamp of the session start.                                            |
| `end_time`       | DATETIME   | NOT NULL                                     | Timestamp of the session end.                                              |
| `duration_secs`  | REAL       | NOT NULL                                     | Duration of the session in seconds.                                        |

**Modified Tables:**

*   **`ocr_text`**: Add a `session_id` column (INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY referencing `sessions.id`).
*   **`audio_transcriptions`**: Add a `session_id` column (INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY referencing `sessions.id`).
*   **`ui_monitoring`**: Add a `session_id` column (INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY referencing `sessions.id`).

**Indexes:**

*   Create indexes on `sessions` table columns (`app_name`, `window_name`, `start_time`, `end_time`) for efficient querying.
*   Create indexes on the `session_id` columns in `ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, and `ui_monitoring`.

### 3.2. API Enhancements

We'll modify the existing `/search` endpoint to also support session queries.

**Request:**

```
GET /search?content_type=session&app_name=Cursor&start_time=2024-11-27T00:00:00Z&end_time=2024-11-28T00:00:00Z&min_duration=60&limit=10&offset=0
```

*   `content_type=session`: Indicates a session-based search.
*   `app_name`, `window_name`: Filter by application and window (optional).
*   `start_time`, `end_time`: Date range for the session (optional, defaults to last 24 hours).
*   `min_duration`, `max_duration`: Filter by session duration in seconds (optional).
*   `limit`, `offset`: Pagination parameters.


after discussing with @louis030195 on discord he proposed something like this as the output

**Response:**

```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "app_name": "Cursor",
      "total_usage_time": 3600,
      "windows": [
        {
          "window_name": "page.tsx",
          "sessions": [
            {
              "start_time": "2024-07-16T12:00:00Z",
              "end_time": "2024-07-16T12:30:00Z",
              "duration": 1800,
              "content_ids": [123, 124, 125],
              "tags": ["coding", "frontend"]
            },
            {
              "start_time": "2024-07-16T14:00:00Z",
              "end_time": "2024-07-16T14:30:00Z",
              "duration": 1800,
              "content_ids": [223, 224, 225],
              "tags": ["coding", "frontend"]
            }
          ],
          "total_usage_time": 3600
        }
      ]
    },
    {
      "app_name": "Arc",
      "total_usage_time": 1200,
      "windows": [
        {
          "window_name": "x.com",
          "sessions": [
            {
              "start_time": "2024-07-16T10:30:00Z",
              "end_time": "2024-07-16T10:50:00Z",
              "duration": 1200,
              "content_ids": [126, 127, 128],
              "tags": ["browsing", "social-media"]
            }
          ],
          "total_usage_time": 1200
        }
      ]
    }
  ],
  "pagination": {
    "limit": 50,
    "offset": 0,
    "total": 2
  }
}
```

### 3.3. Session Boundary Detection Logic

1.  **Real-time Monitoring:**  The existing event listeners for OCR, audio, and UI events will be leveraged.

2.  **Session Tracking:**  Maintain a data structure (likely in memory, possibly augmented with periodic database writes for persistence) to track active sessions.  This structure should map:
    *   `(app_name, window_name)` -> `(session_id, last_activity_timestamp)`

3.  **New Event Handling:**
    *   When a new event (OCR, audio, UI) arrives:
        *   Extract `app_name` and `window_name`.
        *   Check if an active session exists for this (app, window) combination.
        *   If a session exists:
            *   Check if `now() - last_activity_timestamp` exceeds the inactivity timeout.
            *   If timeout exceeded, end the existing session and create a new one.
            *   If not timed out, update `last_activity_timestamp` to the event's timestamp.
        *   If no session exists:
            *   Create a new session with `start_time` and `end_time` set to the event's timestamp.
            *   Generate a new `session_id`.
            *   Insert a new row into the `sessions` table.
        *   Insert the new data (OCR, audio, UI) into the relevant table, linking it to the active `session_id`.

4.  **Inactivity Timeout:** A configurable timeout (e.g., 5 minutes) will be used to determine session end due to inactivity.

5.  **Periodic Flushing:** To avoid excessive in-memory state, periodically flush closed sessions (those that have exceeded the inactivity timeout) to the database.

6. **Data Migration:** A migration script will be needed to analyze existing data and create initial session records based on timestamp proximity and app/window changes.

### 3.4. Implementation Details

*   **Language/Framework:** Continue using Rust for core logic and database interaction.
*   **Database:** Continue using SQLite.
*   **Concurrency:** Use asynchronous operations with `tokio` for handling concurrent events and database interactions.  Leverage `Arc` and `Mutex` for shared state, and channels for communication between tasks.
*   **Configuration:** Add a new setting for the inactivity timeout.
*   **Error Handling:** Implement robust error handling with `anyhow` and propagate errors appropriately. Log errors using `tracing`.
* **Testing:** Thoroughly test session boundary detection with various scenarios, including rapid switching, long inactivity periods, and concurrent events.

## 4. Diagrams

### 4.1. Current Data Flow

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Screen
    participant Microphone
    participant Screenpipe
    participant Database
    User->>Screen: Interacts with screen
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    User->>Microphone: Speaks
    Microphone->>Screenpipe: Captures audio
    Screenpipe->>Database: Stores OCR data with timestamps
    Screenpipe->>Database: Stores audio transcriptions with timestamps
    User->>Screenpipe: Requests data
    Screenpipe->>Database: Queries data by time range
    Database->>Screenpipe: Returns data
    Screenpipe->>User: Returns data
```

### 4.2. Proposed Database Schema Changes

```mermaid
classDiagram
    class frames {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +video_chunk_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +offset_index : INTEGER
        +timestamp : DATETIME
        +name : TEXT
    }
    class video_chunks {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +file_path : TEXT
        +device_name : TEXT
    }
    class ocr_text {
        +frame_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +text : TEXT
        +text_json : TEXT
        +app_name : TEXT
        +window_name : TEXT
        +ocr_engine : TEXT
        +focused : BOOLEAN
        +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
    class audio_chunks {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +file_path : TEXT
        +timestamp : TIMESTAMP
    }
    class audio_transcriptions {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +audio_chunk_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +offset_index : INTEGER
        +timestamp : DATETIME
        +transcription : TEXT
        +device : TEXT
        +is_input_device : BOOLEAN
        +speaker_id : INTEGER
        +transcription_engine : TEXT
        +start_time : REAL
        +end_time : REAL
        +text_length : INTEGER
        +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
    class ui_monitoring {
      +id : INTEGER [PK]
      +text_output : TEXT
      +timestamp : DATETIME
      +app : TEXT
      +window : TEXT
      +initial_traversal_at : DATETIME
      +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
  class sessions {
    +id : INTEGER [PK]
    +app_name : TEXT
    +window_name : TEXT
    +start_time : DATETIME
    +end_time : DATETIME
    +duration_secs : REAL
  }
  frames --|> video_chunks : video_chunk_id
  ocr_text --|> frames : frame_id
  audio_transcriptions --|> audio_chunks : audio_chunk_id
  ocr_text --|> sessions : session_id
  audio_transcriptions --|> sessions : session_id
  ui_monitoring --|> sessions : session_id
```

### 4.3. Modified Data Flow with Session Tracking

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Screen
    participant Microphone
    participant Screenpipe
    participant Session Manager
    participant Database

    User->>Screen: Interacts with App A, Window 1
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: No active session
    Session Manager->>Database: Create new session, get session_id
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store OCR data, link to session_id
    User->>Microphone: Speaks
    Microphone->>Screenpipe: Captures audio
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: Active session found (session_id)
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store audio data, link to session_id

    Note over User,Screenpipe: User switches to App B, Window 2
    User->>Screen: Interacts with App B, Window 2
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App B, Window 2)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: No active session
    Session Manager->>Database: End previous session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager->>Database: Create new session, get session_id
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store OCR data, link to new session_id

    Note over User,Screenpipe: Inactivity Timeout
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for activity
    Session Manager->>Database: End current session (App B, Window 2)
```

### 4.4. New API Endpoint (Modified /search)

The existing `/search` endpoint will be extended to support session-based queries.  No new endpoint is needed.

## 5. Performance Implications

*   **Database:**  The addition of the `sessions` table and foreign keys will add some overhead to write operations.  Proper indexing is crucial to mitigate this.  Read performance for session-based queries should be good with appropriate indexes.
*   **Memory:**  The in-memory session tracking will require additional memory.  The size of this will depend on the number of concurrent users and the configured timeout.  This should be monitored and potentially optimized (e.g., using a more efficient data structure than a simple `HashMap`).
*   **CPU:**  The session boundary detection logic will add some CPU overhead.  This should be minimized by efficient checks and the use of asynchronous operations.

## 6. Migration Path

1.  **Add new `sessions` table.**
2.  **Add `session_id` columns** to `ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, and `ui_monitoring` tables.
3.  **Backfill `session_id`:**  A migration script will be needed to analyze existing data and create initial session records.  This script will need to:
    *   Iterate through existing OCR, audio, and UI data in chronological order.
    *   Apply the session boundary detection logic (described above) to group data into sessions.
    *   Insert corresponding rows into the `sessions` table.
    *   Update the `session_id` foreign key in the existing tables.


## 7. Alternative Approaches

1.  **Session Table per Content Type:** Instead of a single `sessions` table, we could have separate session tables for each content type (e.g., `ocr_sessions`, `audio_sessions`, `ui_sessions`).  This might simplify queries for a specific content type but could make cross-content type analysis more complex.
2.  **No Session Table (Denormalized):** We could add `start_time` and `end_time` directly to the existing tables (`ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, `ui_monitoring`). This would avoid the need for joins when querying for sessions, but could lead to data redundancy and potential inconsistencies.
3.  any other suggestions ????


*   **Language/Framework:** Continue using Rust for core logic and database interaction.
*   **Database:** Continue using SQLite.
*   **Concurrency:** Use asynchronous operations with `tokio` for handling concurrent events and database interactions.  Leverage `Arc` and `Mutex` for shared state, and channels for communication between tasks.
*   **Configuration:** Add a new setting for the inactivity timeout.
*   **Error Handling:** Implement robust error handling with `anyhow` and propagate errors appropriately. Log errors using `tracing`.
* **Testing:** Thoroughly test session boundary detection with various scenarios, including rapid switching, long inactivity periods, and concurrent events.

## 4. Diagrams

### 4.1. Current Data Flow

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Screen
    participant Microphone
    participant Screenpipe
    participant Database
    User->>Screen: Interacts with screen
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    User->>Microphone: Speaks
    Microphone->>Screenpipe: Captures audio
    Screenpipe->>Database: Stores OCR data with timestamps
    Screenpipe->>Database: Stores audio transcriptions with timestamps
    User->>Screenpipe: Requests data
    Screenpipe->>Database: Queries data by time range
    Database->>Screenpipe: Returns data
    Screenpipe->>User: Returns data
```

### 4.2. Proposed Database Schema Changes

```mermaid
classDiagram
    class frames {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +video_chunk_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +offset_index : INTEGER
        +timestamp : DATETIME
        +name : TEXT
    }
    class video_chunks {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +file_path : TEXT
        +device_name : TEXT
    }
    class ocr_text {
        +frame_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +text : TEXT
        +text_json : TEXT
        +app_name : TEXT
        +window_name : TEXT
        +ocr_engine : TEXT
        +focused : BOOLEAN
        +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
    class audio_chunks {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +file_path : TEXT
        +timestamp : TIMESTAMP
    }
    class audio_transcriptions {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +audio_chunk_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +offset_index : INTEGER
        +timestamp : DATETIME
        +transcription : TEXT
        +device : TEXT
        +is_input_device : BOOLEAN
        +speaker_id : INTEGER
        +transcription_engine : TEXT
        +start_time : REAL
        +end_time : REAL
        +text_length : INTEGER
        +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
    class ui_monitoring {
      +id : INTEGER [PK]
      +text_output : TEXT
      +timestamp : DATETIME
      +app : TEXT
      +window : TEXT
      +initial_traversal_at : DATETIME
      +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
  class sessions {
    +id : INTEGER [PK]
    +app_name : TEXT
    +window_name : TEXT
    +start_time : DATETIME
    +end_time : DATETIME
    +duration_secs : REAL
  }
  frames --|> video_chunks : video_chunk_id
  ocr_text --|> frames : frame_id
  audio_transcriptions --|> audio_chunks : audio_chunk_id
  ocr_text --|> sessions : session_id
  audio_transcriptions --|> sessions : session_id
  ui_monitoring --|> sessions : session_id
```

### 4.3. Modified Data Flow with Session Tracking

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Screen
    participant Microphone
    participant Screenpipe
    participant Session Manager
    participant Database

    User->>Screen: Interacts with App A, Window 1
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: No active session
    Session Manager->>Database: Create new session, get session_id
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store OCR data, link to session_id
    User->>Microphone: Speaks
    Microphone->>Screenpipe: Captures audio
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: Active session found (session_id)
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store audio data, link to session_id

    Note over User,Screenpipe: User switches to App B, Window 2
    User->>Screen: Interacts with App B, Window 2
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App B, Window 2)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: No active session
    Session Manager->>Database: End previous session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager->>Database: Create new session, get session_id
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store OCR data, link to new session_id

    Note over User,Screenpipe: Inactivity Timeout
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for activity
    Session Manager->>Database: End current session (App B, Window 2)
```

### 4.4. New API Endpoint (Modified /search)

The existing `/search` endpoint will be extended to support session-based queries.  No new endpoint is needed.

## 5. Performance Implications

*   **Database:**  The addition of the `sessions` table and foreign keys will add some overhead to write operations.  Proper indexing is crucial to mitigate this.  Read performance for session-based queries should be good with appropriate indexes.
*   **Memory:**  The in-memory session tracking will require additional memory.  The size of this will depend on the number of concurrent users and the configured timeout.  This should be monitored and potentially optimized (e.g., using a more efficient data structure than a simple `HashMap`).
*   **CPU:**  The session boundary detection logic will add some CPU overhead.  This should be minimized by efficient checks and the use of asynchronous operations.

## 6. Migration Path

1.  **Add new `sessions` table.**
2.  **Add `session_id` columns** to `ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, and `ui_monitoring` tables.
3.  **Backfill `session_id`:**  A migration script will be needed to analyze existing data and create initial session records.  This script will need to:
    *   Iterate through existing OCR, audio, and UI data in chronological order.
    *   Apply the session boundary detection logic (described above) to group data into sessions.
    *   Insert corresponding rows into the `sessions` table.
    *   Update the `session_id` foreign key in the existing tables.


## 7. Alternative Approaches

1.  **Session Table per Content Type:** Instead of a single `sessions` table, we could have separate session tables for each content type (e.g., `ocr_sessions`, `audio_sessions`, `ui_sessions`).  This might simplify queries for a specific content type but could make cross-content type analysis more complex.
2.  **No Session Table (Denormalized):** We could add `start_time` and `end_time` directly to the existing tables (`ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, `ui_monitoring`). This would avoid the need for joins when querying for sessions, but could lead to data redundancy and potential inconsistencies.
3.  any other suggestions ????

in the desktop app, you can configure hugging face mirror, but for the screenpipe server cli ,there is no such option , when try to use whisper for audio transcription, need to download mode from hugging face

task.title: Support Http Range header on request for Files

data.title: Support Http Range header on request for Files
data.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

The Range HTTP request header indicates the part of a document that the server should return. Several parts can be requested with one Range header at once, and the server may send back these ranges in a multipart document.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Example requesting 3 ranges from files -
`Range: bytes=200-1000, 2000-6576, 19000-`

Send only those parts of the document in Response.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Currently, the range is hardcoded as follows - 
` ctx.write(new DefaultFileRegion(raf.getChannel, 0, fileLength))`
Manipulate the positions as per request headers instead.

**Additional context**

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Range

task.title: Split into multiple modules

data.title: Split into multiple modules
data.body:
Currently, the zio-http artifact contains a lot of different parts of zio-http exclusively. They are not separate maven artifacts.

We want to change this, to support future changes/features.

There should be at least these modules that are published into maven. 

1. core
2. endpoint
3. netty

Should we have client and server in different modules?

task.title: ZStreams buffer(1) is buffering 2.

data.title: ZStreams buffer(1) is buffering 2.
data.body:
I am using zio 2.1.17. When I run the following code:

```scala
def fakeNetworkCall(n: Int): ZIO[Any, Throwable, String] = {
  for {
    _ <- Console.printLine(s"Starting request $n")
    _ <- ZIO.sleep(1.second)
    _ <- Console.printLine(s"Completed request $n")
  } yield s"Response for $n"
}

val program: ZIO[Any, Throwable, Unit] =
  ZStream
    .fromIterator(Iterator.from(1))
    .mapZIO(fakeNetworkCall)
    .buffer(1)
    .runForeach { response =>
      for {
        _ <- Console.printLine(s"Press Enter to process $response...")
        _ <- ZIO.sleep(100.minutes)
        _ <- Console.printLine(s"Processing response $response")
        _ <- ZIO.sleep(1.second)
        _ <- Console.printLine(s"Done processing $response")
      } yield ()
    }
```
The full code is [here](https://scastie.scala-lang.org/douglasthomsen/kvRuhoAGRjarj9djF53N0g/10).

When i get to the `_ <- ZIO.sleep(100.minutes)` line I would expect the output to be like this:
```
Starting request 1
Completed request 1
Starting request 2
Press Enter to process Response for 1...
Completed request 2
```

but I am getting the following:
```
Starting request 1
Completed request 1
Starting request 2
Press Enter to process Response for 1...
Completed request 2
Starting request 3
Completed request 3
```

My goal is to only buffer one call to `fakeNetworkCall` at time. Right now it looks like it is buffering two. I am I doing something wrong or is this a bug?

task.body:
I am using zio 2.1.17. When I run the following code:

```scala
def fakeNetworkCall(n: Int): ZIO[Any, Throwable, String] = {
  for {
    _ <- Console.printLine(s"Starting request $n")
    _ <- ZIO.sleep(1.second)
    _ <- Console.printLine(s"Completed request $n")
  } yield s"Response for $n"
}

val program: ZIO[Any, Throwable, Unit] =
  ZStream
    .fromIterator(Iterator.from(1))
    .mapZIO(fakeNetworkCall)
    .buffer(1)
    .runForeach { response =>
      for {
        _ <- Console.printLine(s"Press Enter to process $response...")
        _ <- ZIO.sleep(100.minutes)
        _ <- Console.printLine(s"Processing response $response")
        _ <- ZIO.sleep(1.second)
        _ <- Console.printLine(s"Done processing $response")
      } yield ()
    }
```
The full code is [here](https://scastie.scala-lang.org/douglasthomsen/kvRuhoAGRjarj9djF53N0g/10).

When i get to the `_ <- ZIO.sleep(100.minutes)` line I would expect the output to be like this:
```
Starting request 1
Completed request 1
Starting request 2
Press Enter to process Response for 1...
Completed request 2
```

but I am getting the following:
```
Starting request 1
Completed request 1
Starting request 2
Press Enter to process Response for 1...
Completed request 2
Starting request 3
Completed request 3
```

My goal is to only buffer one call to `fakeNetworkCall` at time. Right now it looks like it is buffering two. I am I doing something wrong or is this a bug?

task.title: improved `Queue` shutdown functionality

data.title: improved `Queue` shutdown functionality
data.body:
Hey, I've recently proposed something on Discord, and since feedback has been rather positive, I'm making a ticket to track the idea.

I've been working with Queues recently, and I've been having some issues around `shutdown` that I would like to address.

Specifically, I find it a common pattern that I send some kind of request object through a queue because I want another fiber to perform some action on my behalf. Along with the request, I send a `Promise` to have that fiber communicate the outcome of that action to me. By and large this works fine. The issue arises when the fiber that I'm sending requests to fails. In that case, I would like it to communicate the cause of the failure back to the other fibers. This is easy enough for the requests that I've already pulled out of the queue: I simply fail those promises.
But I also need to deal with other cases: fibers currently blocked in an `offer` call, future attempts to `offer` to the queue, and I also need to deal with requests that have been submitted to the queue but not yet retrieved.

So my idea is as follows:
 - add an `E` type parameter to `Queue`
 - add a `shutdownCause` method that takes a type parameter of type `Cause[E]`
 - `shutdownCause` would also return the items currently buffered in the queue in order to dispose of them
 - after `shutdownCause` has been called, any attempt to interact with the queue will fail with the cause
 - methods like `take, offer` etc. should indicate errors of type `E`
 - streams created with `ZStream.fromQueue` would also fail with this cause
 - `shutdownCause` should be atomic: when multiple fibers call it at the same time, one of them wins and the others fail with the cause supplied by the winner

Afaik, adding a new method is a binary compatible change, as is adding a new type parameter. Hence I think this is a source incompatible but binary compatible change. @ghostdogpr therefore suggested it could be added in a ZIO 2.2 release.

task.body:
Hey, I've recently proposed something on Discord, and since feedback has been rather positive, I'm making a ticket to track the idea.

I've been working with Queues recently, and I've been having some issues around `shutdown` that I would like to address.

Specifically, I find it a common pattern that I send some kind of request object through a queue because I want another fiber to perform some action on my behalf. Along with the request, I send a `Promise` to have that fiber communicate the outcome of that action to me. By and large this works fine. The issue arises when the fiber that I'm sending requests to fails. In that case, I would like it to communicate the cause of the failure back to the other fibers. This is easy enough for the requests that I've already pulled out of the queue: I simply fail those promises.
But I also need to deal with other cases: fibers currently blocked in an `offer` call, future attempts to `offer` to the queue, and I also need to deal with requests that have been submitted to the queue but not yet retrieved.

So my idea is as follows:
 - add an `E` type parameter to `Queue`
 - add a `shutdownCause` method that takes a type parameter of type `Cause[E]`
 - `shutdownCause` would also return the items currently buffered in the queue in order to dispose of them
 - after `shutdownCause` has been called, any attempt to interact with the queue will fail with the cause
 - methods like `take, offer` etc. should indicate errors of type `E`
 - streams created with `ZStream.fromQueue` would also fail with this cause
 - `shutdownCause` should be atomic: when multiple fibers call it at the same time, one of them wins and the others fail with the cause supplied by the winner

Afaik, adding a new method is a binary compatible change, as is adding a new type parameter. Hence I think this is a source incompatible but binary compatible change. @ghostdogpr therefore suggested it could be added in a ZIO 2.2 release.

task.title: ZScheduler parks+unparks workers too frequently

data.title: ZScheduler parks+unparks workers too frequently
data.body:
Unparking workers is slow and invoked in the hotpath too often. I think we may need to trade some fairness for aggression to avoid excessive cycling.

`maybeUnparkWorker` (obviously `LockSupport.unpark(worker)`) is very expensive: https://github.com/zio/zio/blob/series/2.x/core/jvm-native/src/main/scala/zio/internal/ZScheduler.scala#L443-L454

task.body:
Unparking workers is slow and invoked in the hotpath too often. I think we may need to trade some fairness for aggression to avoid excessive cycling.

`maybeUnparkWorker` (obviously `LockSupport.unpark(worker)`) is very expensive: https://github.com/zio/zio/blob/series/2.x/core/jvm-native/src/main/scala/zio/internal/ZScheduler.scala#L443-L454

task.title: Can Fiber(Runtime) and Promise be merged?

data.title: Can Fiber(Runtime) and Promise be merged?
data.body:
A Promise awaiting completion is essentially a Fiber parked awaiting an async callback. When a Fiber is forking work (which will eventually complete a promise), then awaiting a Promise, we end up with unnecessary allocations + indirection.

it would be useful to have `Promise.become` or similar to link fibers/promises.

task.body:
A Promise awaiting completion is essentially a Fiber parked awaiting an async callback. When a Fiber is forking work (which will eventually complete a promise), then awaiting a Promise, we end up with unnecessary allocations + indirection.

it would be useful to have `Promise.become` or similar to link fibers/promises.

task.title: Handling errors allows recovering from defects

data.title: Handling errors allows recovering from defects
data.body:
Sigh... Well, this is annoying. When a Cause contains both a failure and a defect (i.e., Fail & Die), failure handling assumes that the Cause does not contain any defects and therefor silently ignores them.

Repro:

```scala
import zio.*

object Foo extends ZIOAppDefault {
  val dieCause: Cause[String] = Cause.die(new RuntimeException("boom"))
  val combinedCause = dieCause && Cause.fail("boom")

  def run = ZIO.failCause(combinedCause).catchAll { e =>
    ZIO.debug(e)
  } *> ZIO.debug("Success")
}
```
prints:
```
handled: boom
Success
```

However if we substituted `ZIO.failCause(combinedCause)` with `ZIO.failCause(dieCause)`:

```
timestamp=2025-05-20T16:31:09.291104Z level=ERROR thread=#zio-fiber-1707930317 message="" cause="java.lang.RuntimeException: boom
	at Foo$.<clinit>(Foo.scala:4)
	at Foo.main(Foo.scala)
	at <empty>.Foo.run(Foo.scala:7)
	at <empty>.Foo.run(Foo.scala:9)
"
```

With both of these causes, the outcome should be the same as defects should always be prioritised over failures. This gets even worse when interruption is involved, because the failure handling will be prioritised over it.

Having said that, this has the potential to massively alter applications so I'm too scared to fix it.
@ghostdogpr @jdegoes  @hearnadam @guizmaii I summon you all for some wisdom

Sigh... Well, this is annoying. When a Cause contains both a failure and a defect (i.e., Fail & Die), failure handling assumes that the Cause does not contain any defects and therefor silently ignores them.

Repro:

```scala
import zio.*

object Foo extends ZIOAppDefault {
  val dieCause: Cause[String] = Cause.die(new RuntimeException("boom"))
  val combinedCause = dieCause && Cause.fail("boom")

  def run = ZIO.failCause(combinedCause).catchAll { e =>
    ZIO.debug(e)
  } *> ZIO.debug("Success")
}
```
prints:
```
handled: boom
Success
```

However if we substituted `ZIO.failCause(combinedCause)` with `ZIO.failCause(dieCause)`:

```
timestamp=2025-05-20T16:31:09.291104Z level=ERROR thread=#zio-fiber-1707930317 message="" cause="java.lang.RuntimeException: boom
	at Foo$.<clinit>(Foo.scala:4)
	at Foo.main(Foo.scala)
	at <empty>.Foo.run(Foo.scala:7)
	at <empty>.Foo.run(Foo.scala:9)
"
```

With both of these causes, the outcome should be the same as defects should always be prioritised over failures. This gets even worse when interruption is involved, because the failure handling will be prioritised over it.

Having said that, this has the potential to massively alter applications so I'm too scared to fix it.
@ghostdogpr @jdegoes  @hearnadam @guizmaii I summon you all for some wisdom

task.title: Scala Native `WeakConcurrentBag` NPE when forking 10K fibers

data.title: Scala Native `WeakConcurrentBag` NPE when forking 10K fibers
data.body:
```
[info]   - PromiseSpec - waiter stack safety
[info]     Exception in thread "zio-fiber-931" java.lang.NullPointerException: null
[info]     	at scala.scalanative.runtime.package$.throwNullPointer(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at <none>.(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentHashMap.treeifyBin(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentHashMap.putVal(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentHashMap$KeySetView.add(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at zio.internal.WeakConcurrentBag.addToLongTermStorage(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at zio.internal.WeakConcurrentBag.add(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at zio.internal.FiberScope$global$.add(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at zio.ZIO$unsafe$.makeChildFiber(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at zio.ZIO$unsafe$.fork(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at zio.ZIO.$anonfun$forkWithScopeOverride$2(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at zio.ZIO$$Lambda$280.apply(Unknown Source)
[info]     	at zio.PromiseSpec.spec(PromiseSpec.scala:127)
[info]     	at zio.PromiseSpec.spec(PromiseSpec.scala:124)
```
I introduced a new test in #9569 which resulted in this strange failure on Native.

task.body:

task.title: Proposal: Add SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor (STM32F405)

data.title: Proposal: Add SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor (STM32F405)
data.body:
Title
Proposal: Add SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor (STM32F405)

Body
Hi TSCircuit team! Id like to propose adding the SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor to the funboards catalog.

- Board: SparkFun MicroMod STM32 Processor (STM32F405RGT6)
- Product page: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/21326
- Hardware repo: https://github.com/sparkfun/MicroMod_STM32_Processor
- Hookup guide: https://learn.sparkfun.com/tutorials/micromod-stm32-processor-hookup-guide
- Schematic (PDF): https://cdn.sparkfun.com/assets/8/a/a/7/3/MicroMod_STM32_Processor.pdf

Why this board
- Expands MicroMod coverage (M.2 E-class 22mm edge) and brings STM32F4 (Cortex-M4) into the catalog.
- Reusable mapping: once the MicroMod edge connector + STM32F405 pins are modeled, other MicroMod processors benefit.
- Complexity: moderate/advanced (MCU, HSE/LSE clocks, boot/reset gating, SPI flash, SDIO, USB, SWD). Seems like a mid-tier bounty candidate.

Duplication check
- I checked the public boards list in `tscircuit/sparkfun-boards/boards/` and did not find this board at time of filing.
- Also glanced at the org project board (https://github.com/orgs/tscircuit/projects/6) and didnt see it in progress. Please correct me if I missed it.

Planned implementation (TSX; no XY tooling)
- Schematic (TSX):
  - `STM32F405RG` (LQFP-64) with VDDx/VDDA/VSSA, `VCAP1/2` decoupling, `PH0/PH1` 12MHz HSE, `PC14/PC15` 32.768kHz LSE.
  - SPI flash W25Qxx (WSON-8 6x5) on SPI1 (PA5/PA6/PA7) + `PC4` CS#; HOLD#/WP# as per schematic.
  - MicroMod edge symbol with named pins: 3.3V, GNDs, `USB_D`, `USB_VIN`, `RTC_3V`, `3.3V_EN`, `!RESET!`, `!BOOT!`, SWDIO/SWCLK, SDIO, SPI, I2C, UART, BUS/GPIO.
  - Boot/reset: `BOOT0` gating via PMOSFET (DMG2305UX7), RC on `NRST`, `PB2` (BOOT1) strapped.
- PCB (TSX):
  - 22mm MicroMod card outline with chamfer; custom edge pad footprint (pads 175) per MicroMod spec.
  - Place LQFP64, crystals (3225/3215), WSON8 flash, decoupling; indicative routing for visuals.
- Artifacts: snapshots/renders via `tsci snapshot`.

Acceptance/questions
- Can you confirm its green to proceed and eligible for a bounty? If so, please attach a bounty and assign.
- Any preference for edge connector footprint naming or a canonical MicroMod footprint I should reuse?
- Any constraints (e.g., minimum visual fidelity for the edge connector, keepout notches, silk expectations)?
- Any components/modules to avoid for funboards? (Ive avoided relying on XY import.)

Estimated effort
- 12 days for faithful schematic + functional PCB visualization (including custom edge footprint) and snapshots.

Thanks! Happy to adapt to preferred structure or scope.
